newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Ireland supports Poland for EU membership.
newsitem.headline: Ireland supports Poland for EU membership.

text.p: Ireland said on Tuesday it would back Polish membership of a bigger European Union (EU).
Prime Minister John Bruton gave the commitment when he had talks with Poland's President Aleksander Kwasniewski who was on a state visit to the Irish capital.
Bruton, speaking to reporters, said he had told Kwasniewski "that Ireland fully supports full Polish membership of the EU".
Kwasniewski, who had said earlier that he would be calling for Irish support for Poland's candidacy, said he was extremely happy about Ireland's unequivocal support.
Talks on enlarging the 15-member trading and political bloc are to be held after an EU inter-governmental conference and the June end of the current Dutch EU presidency.
Bruton visited Poland last April before Ireland took on the six-month EU leadership.

Kwasniewski met Irish President Mary Robinson, spoke to business leaders and later attended a state dinner. On Wednesday he will meet party leaders and hold talks with parliament's foreign affairs and European affairs committees.
